Fletcher Supervision Writing – review & editing Resources Funding acquisition a ⁎ a HySA/Catalysis, Centre for Catalysis Research, University of Cape Town, Private Bag X3, Rondebosch 7701, South Africa HySA/Catalysis, Centre for Catalysis Research, University of Cape Town Private Bag X3 Rondebosch 7701 South Africa HySA/Catalysis, Centre for Catalysis Research, University of Cape Town, Private Bag X3, Rondebosch, 7701, South Africa b HYENA, Hydrogen Energy Applications, 26 Ebony Road, Tokai, Western Cape, South Africa HYENA, Hydrogen Energy Applications 26 Ebony Road Tokai Western Cape South Africa HYENA, Hydrogen Energy Applications, 26 Ebony Road, Tokai, Western Cape, South Africa c Department of Applied Chemistry, University of the Basque Country, Paseo Manuel de Lardizábal 3, 20018 San Sebastián, Spain Department of Applied Chemistry, University of the Basque Country Paseo Manuel de Lardizábal 3 San Sebastián 20018 Spain Department of Applied Chemistry, University of the Basque Country, Paseo Manuel de Lardizábal 3, 20018, San Sebastián, Spain ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 Current affiliation: Dyson Technology Ltd, Tetbury Hill, Malmsbury, SN16 0RP, United Kingdom This study focuses on investigating the intrinsic kinetics of methane steam reforming over a lanthanum promoted Ru/La-Al₂O₃ catalyst at low temperatures ranging from 475 to 550 °C and 140 kPa. To facilitate the research, high-throughput experimentation was employed using 16 integral fixed bed reactors. The steam reforming reaction was influenced by co-reactants and products. In this work, we proposed a reaction mechanism and developed a kinetic model to understand the underlying process. The findings indicate that methane dissociative adsorption is the rate-determining step, and CO is identified as the most abundant surface intermediate. The developed kinetic model not only provides the best fit to the experimental data but also statistically significant and thermodynamically consistent. Graphical Abstract ga1 List of abbreviations MSR Methane Steam Reforming S/C Steam to Carbon ratio La-Al₂O₃ Lanthanum-promoted Alumina BET Brauner-Emmett-Teller HPLC High Pressure Liquid Chromatography WGS Water Gas Shift W/FCH4 Space Time LHHW Langmuir-Hinshelwood-Hougen-Watson SSE sum of the squares of errors XRD X-ray Diffraction GC Gas Chromatography Keywords Methane steam reforming Intrinsic kinetic High throughput experimentation Ruthenium catalyst Lanthanum-promoted alumina Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen is widely recognised as a promising future energy carrier with diverse applications, including the storage of excess energy from intermittent renewables, feedstock for fuel and chemical synthesis, and power generation in fuel cells [1,2]. The European Commission’s net zero scenarios envision the production of green hydrogen through water electrolysis by 2050 [3]. In the interim, methane steam reforming (MSR) and electrolysis are pivotal technologies in the transition towards clean and sustainable hydrogen economy [4,5]. Methane, the most abundant hydrocarbon, serves as the primary component of both renewable (e.g., biomethane, biogas) and non-renewable (e.g., natural gas, shale gas) feedstocks [6,7]. This makes methane a key resource for hydrogen production, particularly through processes such as MSR, which involves two main reactions: the highly endothermic reaction of methane with steam, producing CO and H₂, and the exothermic water gas shift reaction, converting CO into CO₂ and H₂. Traditionally, steam reforming has been carried out on an industrial scale using nickel catalyst in tubular reactors at temperatures above 800 °C, pressure of 20 – 40 bar, and steam-to-carbon ratios (S/C) of 2.5 – 3 [8]. However, in recent years, there has been growing interest in low temperature steam reforming due to its economical and operational advantages [9]. At low temperatures, there are thermodynamic limitations on conversion, but these can be overcome by employing membrane reactor technology [10,11] or by utilizing CO₂ sorption-enhanced steam reforming [12], which can achieve conversion of up to 90%. To facilitate the reaction at low temperature with short residence times, an active catalyst is required. This catalyst must exhibit thermal stability and resistance to carbon formation [9]. These characteristics are important to ensure the efficiency and longevity of the catalyst in low temperature steam reforming process. Transition metal catalysts have indeed shown promising activity in the breakage of the C-H bond of CH₄. At temperatures ranging from 400 to 900 °C and atmospheric pressure, the catalysts exhibit a relative activity order of Rh ∼ Ru > Ni ∼ Ir > Pt ∼ Pd > Co ∼ Fe [13]. However, when considering base metal catalysts such as Ni, Co, and Fe, their use is limited due to lower activity, deactivation issues, and safety concerns [14]. Among these catalysts, Ru has emerged as an ideal candidate for methane steam reforming. It exhibits comparable performance to Rh [15] while demonstrating reduced tendencies for coking and relatively lower cost. The steam reforming reaction is commonly understood as a process involving the adsorption and dissociation of methane and steam on active catalyst sites, followed by surface reactions between the chemisorbed carbon species and oxygen or hydroxyl groups. The catalyst mostly break the C-H bonds of methane [16] and facilitates the dissociation of steam. The choice of catalyst support, typically a high surface area material, can be inert or actively participate in the reaction mechanism. Alumina support, for instance, offers advantages such as lower cost, reasonable stability, high surface area, and desirable porosity [17–19]. Promoters like ZrO₂ [20], CeO₂ [21,22], and La₂O₃ [23–25] can be incorporated into the support, which can further enhance the adsorption and dissociation of steam into oxygen or hydroxyl groups. Furthermore, modifying alumina with lanthanum has been found to be an effective method for improving thermal stability, preserving surface area in a steam environment, and inhibiting coke formation [26–30]. The lanthanum cations in the alumina support can act as additional sites for the dissociative adsorption of steam [31,32], and the resulting OH groups can actively participate in the reaction mechanism, promoting the overall reaction. A relevant example of this is the lanthanum incorporated ETS-10 titanosilicate and its influence on the enhanced activity for CO₂ reforming of methane [33]. The presence of OH species, as reaction intermediate, accelerates the oxidation rates of chemisorbed carbon and also enhances resistance to carbon formation [34]. Considering the higher activity of Ru, the high surface area of alumina, and the thermal stability and resistance to coking offered by lanthanum, Ru supported on lanthanum-promoted alumina has proven to be an effective catalyst for reforming reaction [14,35]. Although the kinetics of methane steam reforming over transition metals catalysts have been extensively studied, there are only a few investigations regarding the kinetics of Ru catalysts [36–40]. Among the limited investigations on Ru catalysts, Jakobsen et al., [38] developed a kinetic expression for methane steam reforming over Ru/ZrO₂ catalyst, which was proposed to be representative of other ruthenium catalysts with negligible support effect, except for La₂O₃. Furthermore, there is a lack of kinetic investigation on lanthanum-promoted ruthenium catalyst for methane steam reforming. In the design, development, and optimisation of a catalyst or reactor for low temperature steam reforming, it is crucial to identify the particular reaction mechanism, rate determining step, and surface species that inhibit the reaction rates [41]. The rate determining step in a reforming catalyst is often reported as either a single or multiple reactions. In most cases, it is attributed to either the methane dissociation or the formation of CO. The dissociative adsorption of methane, which involves the slow activation of the first C-H bond, is predominantly observed at higher temperatures (≥550 °C) [16,37]. Conversely, at low temperatures (≤550 °C), the rate determining step can be either the activation of the C-H bond of methane [38,39] or the slow formation of CO and/or CO₂ from carbon intermediates, depending on the relative rates [40]. There is a consensus on the influence of co-reactant or products on the reaction rate and/or the higher coverage of active sites at low temperatures. However, there is a disagreement regarding the inhibitory effects of certain gases such as H₂O, CO, H₂, and CO₂. This discrepancy may stem from variations in catalyst and support characteristics, preparation methods, or operating conditions [42]. The objective of this study is to experimentally investigate the intrinsic kinetic of low-temperature methane steam reforming over a lanthanum-promoted Ru/La-Al₂O₃ catalyst from 475 to 550 °C and a pressure of 140 kPa using high throughput experimentation. Experiments were conducted to analyse the catalyst’s activity and stability, as well as to identify any mass and heat transfer limitations. Furthermore, the influence of reactants and products species on methane steam reforming was examined. Based on the qualitative analysis, a kinetic mechanism was proposed, and a kinetic expression was developed through data fitting and model discrimination. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation and characterization A 1.5 wt% Ru/3 wt% La-Al₂O₃ catalyst was synthesised using a slurry, which has been previously used for dip coating of structured catalysts and investigated for MSR in earlier studies [14,35]. The catalyst slurry was dried in air at 120 °C for 1 h and then calcined in air at 600 °C for 2 h. The calcined catalyst was crushed using a mortar and pestle, and then sieved to obtain a specific catalyst size. The details of the catalyst synthesis and characterisation can be found in the previous study [14], which reported its BET surface area of 108 m²/g, pore volume of 0.34 cm³ /g, pore diameter of 9.8 nm, Ru dispersion of 2.7%, and Ru particle size of 41 nm. 2.2 Experimental setup The experiments were conducted using the high throughput experimentation technique in a Flowrence® unit provided by Avantium, which consists of a set of 16 parallel packed bed reactors. The reactors were made of quartz tubes with an inner diameter of 2 mm. The catalyst, in the range of 20 – 40 mg, was mixed with SiC particles (125 µm) at a catalyst to SiC ratio of 1 and packed into 15 of the reactors. The 16th reactor served as a blank reactor and was packed only with SiC particles. To ensure uniform temperature distribution, quartz wool and SiC particles (125 µm) were compressed on both sides of the catalyst bed, creating a preheating zone. The vertically mounted down flow reactors were placed in four independent heating blocks, which could be independently controlled, allowing for operation at different temperatures. The gas flow into the reactors was regulated by mass flow controllers and distributed using capillaries, while ensuring an equal pressure drop. Liquid water was fed into the system using an HPLC pump, which distributed it through capillaries to each reactor. Water evaporated at the top of the reactor and mixed with the gas mixture before reaching the top of the packed bed. The feed stream to the reactor consisted of a mixture of gases including CH₄, H₂O, H₂, CO, CO₂, N₂, and He. Nitrogen was used as a diluent, and helium was used as an internal standard for quantification purposes. The reactor outlet stream passed through a condenser and a gas-liquid separator before being fed into the gas chromatography (GC) system for analysis. The reproducibility of the high-throughput experimentation in the Florence unit for MSR was confirmed in the previous study [43], where the relative standard deviation was ≤ 3.8%. In this study, the carbon balance, which indicates the accuracy of carbon quantification, did not exceed ± 1.5% in each experiment. Gas analysis were performed using an Agilent CP-490 micro-GC equipped with molecular sieve (MS5) and COX columns, as well as thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Prior to the experiments, the fresh catalyst was heated to 600 °C in a nitrogen flow at a rate of 2 °C/min. It was then activated through an in-situ reduction process using a flow of 50% H₂ in nitrogen for 1 h. Preliminary tests were conducted to ensure catalyst stability for methane steam reforming. The operating conditions were explored to avoid any mass transport limitations by varying the flow rate and catalyst particle sizes. Once it was confirmed that the reaction was proceeding in the kinetic region and far from equilibrium, the dependence of reaction rate on the reactants and products was evaluated. This evaluation was carried out at temperatures ranging from 500 to 600°C, pressure of 140 kPa, He/CH₄ = 0.1, and balanced with nitrogen. The reaction rates were corrected to account for the approach to equilibrium to determine the forward reaction rates. Kinetic experiments were conducted in integral reactors by varying the catalyst amount and flow rates at 475–550 °C, 140 kPa, S/C of 3, H₂/CH₄ of 1, and He/CH₄ of 0.1. The W/F ratio, which represents the ratio of catalyst amount to the inlet methane flow rate, was adjusted by varying both parameters. To assess the departure from equilibrium, the approach to equilibrium ( ƞ SR = P CO × P H 2 3 P CH 4 × P H 2 O 1 K eq , MSR ) for MSR and approach to equilibrium ( ƞ WGS = P CO 2 × P H 2 P CO × P H 2 O 1 K eq , WGS ) for WGS were calculated. Here, K eq , MSR is the equilibrium constant for MSR, K eq , WGS is the equilibrium constant for water gas shift reaction, and P CH 4 , P H 2 O , P CO , P H 2 , P CO 2 are the partial pressures of methane, steam, carbon monoxide, hydrogen, and carbon dioxide, respectively. The approach to equilibrium for MSR was consistently below 0.2 in all the experiments, indicating a significant departure from equilibrium. On the other hand, the water gas shift reaction reached equilibrium, as confirmed by the approach to equilibrium values ranging from 0.80 to 1.35. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst stability The stability of the catalyst was evaluated for a duration of 175 h at a temperature of 700 °C, pressure of 140 kPa, 3 kg cat . s / mol CH 4 , S/C of 3.0, CH₄/H₂ of 1, He/CH₄ of 0.1, and balanced with nitrogen. As depicted in Fig. 1, methane conversion initially exhibited a slight decrease within the first 25 h. However, after this initial period, the methane conversion reached a stable value of 65.1 ± 2.6%. It is important to note that this stable value is significantly lower than the thermodynamic equilibrium value of 92.6%. The initial decline in catalyst activity during the first 25 h can be attributed to surface restructuring, which is a common phenomenon observed in catalysts. However, after this period, the catalyst activity stabilised, and all the subsequent experiments were conducted using the catalyst in its stable state. This stability evaluation ensured that the catalyst has achieved a steady state activity, allowing for reliable and consistent experimental results for kinetic investigation of methane steam reforming. 3.2 Mass and heat transport limitations To investigate external mass transfer limitations, preliminary experiments were conducted by varying the flow rate from 18.7 to 64.1 mL/min through each reactor at 450–600 °C, 140 kPa, 3 kg cat . s / mol CH 4 , S/C = 3.0, He/CH₄ = 0.1, and balanced nitrogen. Fig. 2 illustrates that methane conversion was significantly influenced by external mass transfer limitations for flow rates below 46 mL/min. External mass transfer limitation occurs when there is a concentration gradient between the bulk gas and the catalyst surface, leading to a decline in conversion. This limitation arises from the slower transport of reactants to the catalyst surface. An exponential increase in conversion was observed with increasing flow rates between 30 and 46 mL/min. This indicates a decrease in the concentration gradient across the gas film surrounding the catalyst particles, reducing the external mass transfer limitations. At the flow rates above 46 mL/min, the methane conversion profile remained stable, indicating the absence of external mass transfer limitations. This means that the transport of reactants to the catalyst surface was not impeded, allowing for efficient conversion of methane. To assess intraparticle mass transfer limitations, experiments were also conducted with different particle sizes ranging from 69 to 390 µm at 450–600 °C, 140 kPa, 2.1 kg cat . s / mol CH 4 , S/C = 3.0, He/CH₄ = 0.1 and balanced nitrogen. The impact of catalyst particle size on methane conversion is shown in Fig. 3. For particles sizes ≤ 125 µm, methane conversion remained stable, indicating the absence of intraparticle mass transport limitations. In this size range, the transport of reactants within the catalyst particles was efficient, allowing for effective conversion of methane. However, for particle size ≥ 125 µm, a decrease in methane conversion was observed, suggesting the development of concentration gradients within the catalyst particles. This indicates the presence of intraparticle mass transfer limitations, where the diffusion of reactants becomes slower within the larger catalyst particles. To ensure the absence of intraparticle mass transfer limitations, all subsequent experiments were conducted using catalyst particle with a size of 125 µm. Additionally, the flow rates were maintained at ≥ 46 mL/min to ensure efficient transport of reactants and minimize any external mass transfer limitations. The steam reforming reaction is a strongly endothermic, which can result in temperature gradient inside the catalyst particle or between the bulk gas and the catalyst surface, potentially affecting the reaction rate. To assess the presence of heat transfer limitation, the criteria proposed by Mears [44] were used for external heat transfer limitation Δ H Rxn o r obs ρ cat d p E h f T 2 R < 0.3 and intraparticle heat transfer limitation Δ H Rxn o r obs ρ cat d p E λ p T 2 R < 3.0 . Here, Δ H Rxn o represents the reaction enthalpy (kJ/mol), r obs is the observed reaction rate, ρ cat density of catalyst bed, d p is diameter of the catalyst particle, E is the reaction activation energy (94.5 kJ/mol), h f is the gas to solid heat transfer coefficient (W/m.K), R is the universal gas constant (J/mol.K), T is the temperature (K), and λ p is the solid thermal conductivity (W/m.K). The calculation details of h f and λ p are outlined in the Supporting Information. The maximum values of these criteria were found to be less than 6.4E-4 < 0.3 for the external heat transfer limitation criterion and also less than 4.2E-3 < 3.0 for the intraparticle heat transfer limitation criterion. These values indicate that there are no significant heat transfer limitations under the investigated conditions, suggesting efficient heat transfer between the catalyst and the surrounding. 3.3 Effect of reactants and products partial pressure Qualitative analysis of methane steam reforming was carried out by varying the partial pressure of reactants and products to explore reaction mechanism and explain the kinetic observation. The dependency of the reaction rate on methane partial pressure (4.3 – 12 kPa) was tested under the following conditions: P H 2 O = 27.9 kPa, S/C = 2.3 – 6.5, 500 – 600 °C, 140 kPa, He/CH₄ = 0.1, and balanced nitrogen. Table 1 shows that the reaction rate exhibited first order dependence on methane and was directly proportional to the methane partial pressure ( Fig. 4). The observed first order dependence on methane suggests that the rate-controlling step could be either the mass transfer of methane from the bulk gas to the catalyst surface or the slow activation of the C-H bond. However, since the experiments were conducted in the absence of transport limitations, as explained in Section 3.2, the mass transfer from the bulk fluid to the catalyst surface can be ruled out as a potential rate determining step. Therefore, it can be concluded that the slow activation of the first C-H bond of methane governs the reaction rate. This finding provides a valuable insight into the reaction mechanism and helps explain the observed kinetics of methane steam reforming. Jakobsen et al. [38] proposed that methane dissociative adsorption acts as the rate determining step for steam and CO₂ methane reforming over Ru/ZrO₂ at temperature ranging from 425 to 575°C and pressure of 1.3 bar. Berman at al. [37] investigated the kinetics of MSR (methane steam reforming) on Ru/Mn-Al₂O₃ catalysts and found that the reaction orders for methane were less than 1 at 450 – 500 °C and approximately 1 at 700 – 900 °C. Another study on MSR over Ru/MgO catalyst [39] reported that the reaction followed first order kinetics with respect to methane at temperatures ranging from 550 to 650 °C and atmospheric pressure. Wei and Iglesia [36] proposed the dissociation of methane as the rate determining step for steam and CO₂ reforming over Ru catalyst at temperature of 550 – 750 °C and pressure of 1 – 5 bar. The reaction exhibited first order kinetics with respect to methane and was independent of co-reactants or products. The studies mentioned by Jakobsen et al., [38], Berman et al., [37], and Wei and Iglesia [36], provide further evidence that the dissociative adsorption of methane is a rate-determining step in methane steam reforming reactions over various Ru-based catalysts. These studies report similar findings of first-order kinetics with respect to methane and indicate that the reaction rate is primarily influenced by the activation of the C-H bond in methane. The breakage of the first C-H bond is a critical step and can occur through three pathways: direct CH4 dissociation, O-assisted CH₄ dissociation, and OH-assisted methane dissociation [13]. According to the Hibbitts et al. [45], for catalysts such as Ru, Rh, Pd, Os, and Ir, the activation barrier for direct methane dissociation is much lower than OH-assisted CH₄ dissociation, and both are lower compared to O-assisted CH₄ dissociation. Similarly, the lowest activation barrier was identified for CH₃ dissociation among the three pathways. The rate of dehydrogenation reaction increases as hydrogen atoms are abstracted from CH4. Furthermore, the activation of the C-H bonds in CH₃ and CH₂ through direct dissociation was found to be energetically favourable compared to the other two pathways [42]. In this study, direct methane dissociation is assumed to occur over the Ru catalyst, resulting in the breaking of the C-H bond down to adsorbed C species [46]. One interesting contradiction in literature [47] is the contrasting positive [39] and negative [37] reaction orders concerning steam. To investigate the impact of steam partial pressure (10.1 – 33 kPa), experiments were conducted at P CH 4 = 5.07 kPa, S/C of 2 – 6.5, temperature ranging from 500 to 600 °C and a pressure of 140 kPa. Steam exhibited a positive effect ( Fig. 5), indicating a partially positive order (∼ 0.1) with respect to steam. This finding indicates that steam or its dissociative species do not compete with methane for adsorption on the same active sites. It is possible that two distinct active sites were responsible for the activation of methane and steam, leading to their independent contribution to the overall reaction rate. The incorporation of lanthanum cations into the catalyst support can provide additional active sites for the dissociative adsorption of steam into hydroxyl groups [31,32]. This increased concentration of hydroxyl groups on the support may facilitate subsequent reactions with carbon species [48]. The OH-groups may either spill over from the support onto the Ru metal surface or react with carbonaceous species on Ru active sites at the metal support interface. In the case of spill over, the OH-groups and their dissociation products (O and H) would occupy Ru active sites, resulting in a negative reaction order with respect to steam, reported in the study [37]. This scenario would imply that OH-group compete with methane for the active sites, inhibiting the reaction rate. However, in this study, the observed partially positive reaction order suggests that OH-groups may reside on the support rather than occupying Ru active sites. In this case, the OH-group on the support can oxidise chemisorbed carbon species on Ru at the metal support interface, enhancing the reaction rate of CO formation reaction and facilitating the methane steam reforming reaction. Bradford and Vannice [49] reported a kinetic model for Ni catalyst on MgO and TiO₂ supports, which involves the interface reaction between OH-group on the support and CHx groups on Ni. In case of CO₂ reforming of methane on Pt/ZrO₂ catalysts, Bitter et al. [50] observed that the reaction rate was proportional to the length of the metal-support interface. This emphasizes the significance of the metal-support interface area in reaction kinetics. The dependency of the reaction rate on carbon monoxide was investigated by varying its partial pressure from 0 to 29 kPa at P C H 4 = 20.7 kPa, S/C = 3, 500–600 °C and 140 kPa. The results indicate that the reaction rate was decreased at higher CO partial pressure ( Fig. 6), exhibiting a negative reaction order of − 0.45 at 500 °C and − 0.32 at 600 °C. This suggests that CO molecules were adsorbed on the Ru catalyst, thereby obstructing the active sites responsible for the dehydrogenation of methane. This highlights that optimising the catalyst design and operating conditions to minimise the adsorption of CO and maximize the availability of active sites for methane dehydrogenation can enhance the efficiency of the methane steam reforming process. The experiment involved varying the partial pressure of hydrogen from 0 to 36.3 kPa investigates its impact on reaction rates. This investigation was conducted at P C H 4 = 20.7 kPa, S/C = 3, He/CH₄ = 0.1 and balanced nitrogen. Hydrogen exhibited a mild inhibitory effect on the reaction rate ( Fig. 7), with reaction orders of − 0.12 and − 0.08 at temperatures of 500 and 600 °C, respectively. At higher temperatures, the inhibitory effect diminished due to weakened adsorption, as indicated by the trend in reaction order. The lower values suggest that CO formation was not the rate determining step. Otherwise, the hydrogen inhibition would be of the order ∼2.5 or 3. The negative order could be attributed to the occupation of active sites by hydrogen, suppression of the sequential loss of the chemisorbed hydrogen atom from dehydrogenation reactions, or thermodynamics promoting the reactions such as reverse water gas shift reaction, methanation reaction, and reverse MSR reaction [51,52]. The effect of CO₂ partial pressure (ranging from 0 to 36.3 kPa) on reaction rates was also investigated at P C H 4 = 20.7 kPa, S/C = 3, and 140 kPa. The experimental results showed no significant effect of CO₂ on reaction rates ( Fig. 8), with apparent reaction orders of 0.03 and 0.01 at 500 and 600 °C, respectively. This observation can be attributed to the role of CO₂ as a secondary product formed from CO via water gas shift reaction. Carrara et al., [53] reported the reaction of CO₂ with La₂O₃ support, forming La₂(CO₃)₃ during CO₂ reforming over Ru/La₂O₃. This reaction accelerates the transformation of chemisorbed CHx species. However, the properties of lanthanum-doped alumina differ significantly from those of bulk material [54,55]. According to Haack et al. [56], lanthanum interacting with alumina does not form any lanthanum oxycarbonate when exposed to CO2. The absence of lanthanum peak in the XRD pattern of Ru/La-Al₂O₃ [14] might be due to the high dispersion of La species dissolved in alumina [57,58]. These findings explain the zero-order dependence on CO₂ in the presence of lanthanum, ruling out the possibility of CO₂ competing with steam for adsorption sites on the support, and thus, the kinetics of methane steam reforming were not affected by the CO₂ partial pressure. 3.4 Kinetic experiments The kinetic experiments were conducted to study methane steam reforming at different temperatures, with a fixed steam-to-carbon ratio, by varying the residence time. Under the investigated conditions, the blank reactor filled with SiC particles showed no methane conversion, confirming the absence of non-catalytic and gas phase reactions. This implies that the steam reforming reaction only occurred in the presence of the catalyst, and the following boundary condition holds, x CH 4 = 0 at W F CH 4 = 0 . Fig. 9 illustrates the profiles of methane conversion were plotted as a function of residence time in at different operating temperatures. As explained in Section 3.5, the formation of CO₂ from methane via reverse methanation reaction is unlikely. It is probable that CO₂ is formed exclusively out of CO via water gas shift reaction, which was at equilibrium. This renders both the water gas shift reaction and reverse methanation reaction kinetically irrelevant. However, the profile of methane conversion to CO₂ versus the residence time ( W / F CH 4 ) is depicted in Fig. S1, and a polynomial model with parameters is provided in the Supporting Information. The relationship between methane conversion and space time was correlated using the following second-degree polynomial equations, and the values of the fitted parameters ( a 0 , a 1 , and a 2 ) are listed in Table 2. (1) x CH 4 = a 0 + a 1 W cat F CH 4 + a 2 W cat F CH 4 2 The experimental rates of reaction were determined using the first derivative of the polynomial equations of methane conversion (Eq. 1). (2) r CH 4 = dx CH 4 d W cat / F CH 4 = a 1 + 2 a 2 W cat F CH 4 The rate constant ( k ) and the adsorption constant ( K i ) are temperature dependent and can be described by the Arrhenius and the van’t Hoff equations to determine the unknown parameters. (3) k = k 0 exp − E a RT (4) K i = K i , 0 exp − ∆ H i RT where, k 0 is the pre-exponential factor, E a is the activation energy, R is the universal gas constant (8.314 J/mol/K), T is the temperature in K, K i , 0 is the pre-exponential factor of adsorption constant, and ∆ H i is the adsorption enthalpy. The activation energy and adsorption enthalpy were determined by plotting ln( 1 / k ) and ln( 1 / K i ) versus 1/T within the operating temperature range. 3.5 Thermodynamic analysis In methane steam reforming, various gases, such as CH₄, H₂O, CO, CO₂, and H₂, can be produced. However, there is also a possibility of carbon formation. Previous studies [51,59,60] have considered a total of 11 possible reactions (R1 – R11) in methane steam reforming. To assess the thermodynamic potential for carbon formation reactions (R6 – R11), the carbon activity was utilized as an indicator [61,62]. The carbon activity is determined experimentally based on the composition of the product gas mixture and thermodynamic equilibrium (refer to Table S9 in the Supporting Information). A carbon activity value greater than 1 signifies a thermodynamic potential for carbon formation. In this study, by employing a steam to carbon ratio of 3 and H₂/CH₄ ratio of 1.0 in the feed stream, the carbon activity values for reactions R6 – R11 in the product stream were found to be less than 1.0 (Fig. S3, Supporting Information). This indicates that no carbon formation occurred under the investigated conditions. (R1) CH 4 + H 2 O ↔ CO + 3 H 2 (R2) CO + H 2 O ↔ CO 2 + H 2 (R3) CH 4 + 2 H 2 O ↔ CO 2 + 4 H 2 (R4) CH 4 + CO 2 ↔ 2 CO + 2 H 2 (R5) CH 4 + 3 CO 2 ↔ 4 CO + 2 H 2 O (R6) CH 4 ↔ C + 2 H 2 (R7) 2 CO ↔ C + CO 2 (R8) CO + H 2 ↔ C + H 2 O (R9) CO 2 + 2 H 2 ↔ C + 2 H 2 O (R10) CH 4 + 2 CO ↔ 3 C + 2 H 2 O (R11) CH 4 + CO 2 ↔ 2 C + 2 H 2 O The thermodynamic potential of reactions R1 – R5 was determined using the ratio V j = ( ∏ i P i v i ) / K eq i based on experimental results. A value less than 1 indicates that the reaction proceeds forward, while a value greater than 1 indicates a tendency to approach equilibrium or proceeds backward. For dry reforming reactions R4 – R5, the V j values were found to be less than 1 (Fig. S4, Supporting Information), indicating that these reactions proceed forward. However, it was observed that at higher contact times, the methane reaction rate decreases, while methane conversion and CO₂ concentration increase. This contrast with reactions R4 – R5 proceeding forward suggests that these reactions may occur at very slow rates. Therefore, from a kinetic point of view, these are not considered as possible reactions in this study. The water gas shift (WGS) reaction was assumed to be at thermodynamic equilibrium for V 2 values ranging from 0.80 to 1.40. It is assumed that the WGS reaction produces an equilibrium amount of CO₂ from CO and is kinetically irrelevant. For methane steam reforming reaction, the values of V 1 were found to be less than 1, indicating that the reaction proceeds forward. producing CO and H₂. As for the reverse methanation reaction R3, the values of V 3 were also less than 1, indicating that this reaction can also proceed forward. However, as described in Section 3.2, it was observed that the methane reaction rate was not affected by the partial pressure of CO₂, with a reaction order of 0.01 – 0.03. This suggests that CO₂ is not a primary product from R3 and direct CO₂ formation from CH4 is unlikely. Instead, CO₂ is a secondary product formed exclusively from CO through water gas shift reaction. Additionally, the values of carbon activity of R7 increase with W / F CH 4 as shown in Fig. S5 in the Supporting Information. The extrapolation of the fitted curve leads to the origin, indicating that CO₂ is exclusively produced out of CO and the reaction mechanism without parallel production of CO₂ is required. 3.6 Kinetic modelling 3.6.1 Proposed reaction mechanism Based on the qualitative analysis (Section 3.3) and thermodynamic analysis, a reaction mechanism consisting of a sequence of 10 elementary reaction steps (R12 – R21) has been proposed to describe the methane steam reforming reaction (R1). • Dissociative-adsorption of methane on active sites of Ru, followed by the dehydrogenation of chemisorbed species i.e., CH 3 * , CH 2 * , CH * , C * , and H * [46]. • Dissociative-adsorption of water to species ( OH − S and H − S ) on the lanthanum cations in the support. It is assumed that the dissociation of water on the support is the dominant pathway, although the dissociation on the active sites of Ru is not excluded. • The chemisorbed species i.e., C * and OH − S react at the metal-support interface, yielding COH * specie on Ru active site and the vacant support site [63–65]. • The reactive intermediate COH * interact with the adjacent vacant site on Ru and forms CO * and H * , followed by the desorption of CO and H 2 . (R12) CH 4 + 2 * ↔ CH 3 * + H * (R13) CH 3 * + * ↔ CH 2 * + H * (R14) CH 2 * + * ↔ CH * + H * (R15) CH * + * ↔ C * + H * (R16) C * + OH − S ↔ COH * + S (R17) COH * + * ↔ CO * + * (R18) CO * ↔ CO + * (R19) H * ↔ 1 2 H 2 + * (R20) H − S ↔ 1 2 H 2 + S (R21) H 2 O + 2 S ↔ OH − S + H − S In addition to the proposed reaction mechanism and considering the first order dependence of reaction rate on methane partial pressure, a second reaction mechanism is hypothesised to develop a kinetic model based on the methane adsorption as the rate determining step. A set of elementary reactions is provided in the Supporting Information (S2). According to this mechanism: • Methane undergoes adsorption on Ru active sites in a single step, leading to the formation of chemisorbed methane. • CH₄* dissociates via dehydrogenation reactions in steps, producing C* and H* species. • Steam is assumed to be adsorbed on the support and undergoes dissociation reactions on the lanthanum cations, forming OH-S and H-S species. • CO is formed via the surface oxidation of adsorbed carbon (C*) with OH-S at the metal support interface, followed by the desorption of CO and H 2 . 3.6.2 Langmuir-Hinshelwood-Hougen-Watson kinetic model The Langmuir-Hinshelwood-Hougen-Watson (LHHW) model is commonly used approach to describes the complex surface chemistry of catalytic reactions. The rate expression of LHHW kinetic model is generalised as follows: (5) r = kinetic factor . ( driving force ) ( adsorption term ) n In this rate expression, the kinetic factor represents the dependence of the reaction rate on the rate determining step (RDS) of the reaction mechanism. It focuses on the slowest individual reaction or a set of reactions that determine the overall reaction rate. The other reaction steps in the mechanism are assumed to be at quasi-equilibrium, meaning their rates are much faster compared to the rate determining step. The driving force in the rate expression considers the reaction equilibrium, which is calculated as ( 1 − ƞ SR ) for steam reforming of methane, where ƞ SR represents the approach to equilibrium, as explained in Section 2.2. The adsorption term in the denominator of the rate expression considers the availability of free active sites on the catalyst surface. The occupancy of these sites can be affected by the adsorption of reactant, reaction intermediates, and/or products. The exponent ‘n′ of the adsorption term indicates the number of unoccupied active sites involved in the rate determining step [66]. In this study, kinetic models were developed by considering different rate-determining steps using the LHHW approach and Freundlich’s nonideal adsorption concept. In the qualitative analysis conducted in Section 3.3, it was observed that the reaction rate exhibited a first order dependence on methane partial pressure. This finding suggests that the activation of the C-H bond could potentially be the rate determining step. In this study, three rate determining steps were considered for kinetic expression, namely: methane dissociative adsorption (widely accepted as the most likely RDS), dehydrogenation of the CH₃* surface species, or adsorption of methane on Ru active sites. A rate expression was derived by assuming methane dissociative adsorption (CH₄ + 2 * → CH₃* + H*) as the rate determining step, denoted as R12. The other reactions (R13-R21) were assumed to be at quasi-equilibrium. This rate expression captures the proposed reaction mechanism discussed in Section 3.6 and a mathematical representation of the rate of the methane steam reforming reaction based on the chosen rate determining step is provides here. (6) r = k P CH 4 1 − ƞ SR 1 + K CH 3 P CO P H 2 5 / 2 P H 2 O + K CH 2 P CO P H 2 2 P H 2 O + K CH P CO P H 2 3 / 2 P H 2 O + K C P CO P H 2 P H 2 O + K COH P CO P H 2 1 / 2 + K CO P CO + K H P H 2 1 / 2 2 In a previous microkinetic modelling study [67] on the steam and dry reforming of methane using a Rh catalyst, a first order dependence of reaction rate on methane was observed. In that study, the main pathway for CO formation involved the oxidation of adsorbed carbon (C*) through the reaction C* + OH* → CO* + H* . The experimental results were well-described by a rate expression that considered the dehydrogenation of CH₃* as the rate determining step. For the proposed reaction mechanism discussed in Section 3.6, a rate expression was also derived for dehydrogenation of CH₃* (CH₃* + * → CH₂* + H*) as the rate determining step, denoted as R13. Meanwhile, the other reactions (R12, R14-R21) were assumed to be at quasi equilibrium. The rate expression CH₃* dehydrogenation is as follows: (7) r = k P CH 4 P H 2 1 / 2 ( 1 − ƞ SR ) 1 + K CH 3 P CO P H 2 5 / 2 P H 2 O + K CH 2 P CO P H 2 2 P H 2 O + K CH P CO P H 2 3 / 2 P H 2 O + K C P CO P H 2 P H 2 O + K COH P CO P H 2 1 / 2 + K CO P CO + K H P H 2 1 / 2 2 Based on the second assumed reaction mechanism described in Section 3.6.1, a third kinetic model was derived by assuming that methane adsorption (CH₄ + * → CH₄*) is the rate determining step, while considering other reactions to be at quasi-equilibrium. The rate expression is as follows: (8) r = k P CH 4 ( 1 − ƞ SR ) 1 + K CH 4 P CO P H 2 3 P H 2 O + K CH 3 P CO P H 2 5 / 2 P H 2 O + K CH 2 P CO P H 2 2 P H 2 O + K CH P CO P H 2 3 / 2 P H 2 O + K C P CO P H 2 P H 2 O + K COH P CO P H 2 1 / 2 + K CO P CO + K H P H 2 1 / 2 3.7 Parameter estimation and model discrimination The derived rate expressions (6 − 8) based on the kinetic modelling (section 2.6) were further reformulated into 29 rate expressions by incorporating various combinations of surface species (clean surface, CH₄, CH₃, CH₂, CH, C, COH, H, CO, and H+CO) in the denominator. These rate expressions were then used for parameter estimation by fitting them to the experimental data, followed by model discrimination. The parameters of the kinetic models were estimated by minimising the sum of the squares of errors (SSE) between the experimental and calculated rates, which is a well-established objective function in the kinetic investigation of methane steam reforming [60,68]. This parameter estimation was achieved through nonlinear regression using the Levenberg Marquardt algorithm in Minitab. (9) SSE = ∑ k = 1 N exp r CH 4 , exp − r CH 4 , model 2 During the process of model discrimination, two criteria were used to determine the most suitable kinetic model that provides the best fit to the experimental data. The first criterion was based on physical characterization of the estimated parameters. Models were rejected if they yield negative kinetic constants or if the activation energies fall outside the expected range for methane steam reforming reaction [59]. The second criterion relies on statistical analysis to evaluate the goodness of fit of the models. In this case, models the adjusted coefficient of determination (Adj-R2) values greater than 0.90 were considered to have a high level of fit to the experimental data. Additionally, the models were compared based on their Sum of Squares Error (SSE) values. Models with lower SSE values were preferred as they indicated a closer match between the predicted rates from the kinetic models and the experimental rates. Table 3 presents the four rate expressions that demonstrated the best agreement with the experimental rates. Among these, three models (RE2 – RE4) were identified where CO serves as the most abundant surface intermediate covering the active sites, resulting in the best agreement with the experimental data. This observation is consistent with the experimental finding of a negative partial order (−0.45 at 400 °C and −0.32 at 500 °C) dependence of reaction rate on the partial pressure of carbon monoxide, as described in Section 3.3. In contrast, models that incorporated hydrogen ( K H P H 2 1 / 2 ) in the denominator did not yield statistically significant values, despite the observed slightly negative partial order (−0.12 at 400 °C and −0.08 at 500 °C) dependence of the reaction rate on the hydrogen partial pressure, as described in Section 3.3. The mild inhibition of hydrogen may have influenced the reversibility of the reaction [51,52], and this aspect was taken into account in the models through the inclusion of the thermodynamic driving term ( 1 − ƞ SR ) . It is indeed significant to note that carbon intermediates (C, CH, CH₂, and CH₃) exhibit faster consumption rates on the ruthenium surface [46], and their equilibrium concentration may be insignificant. It is unlikely that the surface species, including C, CH, CH₂, and CH₃ have significant surface coverage on the Ru active sites [46]. Consequently, the terms K CH 3 P CO P H 2 5 / 2 P H 2 O , K CH 2 P CO P H 2 2 P H 2 O , K CH P CO P H 2 3 / 2 P H 2 O , K C P CO P H 2 P H 2 O , and K COH P CO P H 2 1 / 2 were estimated to be minimal based on discrimination criteria and were therefore eliminated from the denominator of Eqs. (6 – 8). Similarly, the model with adsorbed methane specie in the denominator did not provide good agreement with the experimental rates. Furthermore, the absence of O and OH in the denominator suggests that these species do not compete with methane for active sites. This observation aligns with the finding of a partial positive order for steam, as described in Section 3.3, indicating that steam or its dissociative products do not inhibit the reaction rate under the investigated conditions. The absence of competition between methane and steam indicates two distinctive active sites for methane and steam adsorption. The promoting effect of steam on the oxidation of surface carbon species (R16) is facilitated by the spill-over of dissociative oxidative species from lanthanum sites in the alumina support to the ruthenium active sites. This behaviour can be attributed to the non-monotonic dependency of reaction rate on the steam partial pressure, as shown in Fig. 5 of Section 3.3. The partial pressure of steam may influence the approach to equilibrium, and this is accounted for in the kinetic models through the thermodynamic driving term ( 1 − ƞ SR ) . The rate expression RE1 assumes a clean catalyst surface without any adsorbed surface species and corresponds to RE2 and RE4 without the adsorption term in the LHHW model. However, this model is deemed statistically insignificant and rejected based on lower adj-R2 values below 0.90 and higher SSE values. These statistical metrics suggest that the model does not accurately capture the kinetics of methane steam reforming reaction under the investigated conditions. It is worth noting that the estimated activation energy of 71.6 kJ/mol for RE1 is lower than the value of 91 kJ/mol reported in a similar model by Wei and Iglesia [36]. This difference in activation energy can be attributed to variation in support characteristics and the inhibitory effect of surface species observed at lower temperatures, which complies with the findings as described in Section 3.3. RE2 represents methane adsorption as the rate determining step, with CO* as the most abundant surface intermediate. It corresponds to the rate expression derived for methane steam reforming over Rh/Al₂O₃ [69]. However, RE2 is also statistically insignificant and is not further considered, as it exhibits an adj-R2 value of only 0.80, which lower than the threshold of 0.90 for the adsorption equilibrium constant. RE3, which includes CH₃* dissociation, exhibits poor fitting in the temperature range of 475 – 500 °C, with an adj-R2 below the threshold of 0.90. Therefore, this model is also rejected based on statistical grounds. The rate expression RE4 assumes that methane dissociative adsorption is the rate limiting step, with CO as the most abundant reactive intermediate. By considering the physical and statistical criteria, this model demonstrates an excellent fit to the experimental data, making it the most suitable kinetic model. It exhibits statistically significant values, such as adj-R2 greater than 0.9 and the lowest SSE values. The Arrhenius plot, depicted in Fig. 10, illustrates the temperature-dependent variation in both the kinetic rate constant and the adsorption constant of CO. The hydroxyl groups participate in the reaction mechanism and enhances the oxidation rates of carbon species [58,70], meanwhile methane acts to restore the chemisorbed carbon species. This phenomenon could explain the relatively slower rates observed for methane dissociative adsorption, thus making it the rate determining step. Additionally, as shown in Fig. 11, the parity plot further confirms the reliability and validity of the developed model (RE4) by demonstrating the good agreement between the predicted and experimental reaction rates. In this study, the activation energy determined by RE4 model was found to be 94.5 kJ/mol, which agrees well with both theoretical and experimental values reported in the literature, ranging from 78 to 140 kJ/mol. Although the activation energy values of RE1 to RE3 are similar to those reported in literature, these models are rejected based on second discrimination criterion of statistical analysis due to a poor goodness of fit. According to the density functional theory, the activation energies for methane dissociation on ruthenium were approximated to be 78 kJ/mol [71] and 85 kJ/mol [72]. Wei and Iglesia [16] measured an activation energy of 91 kJ/mol for MSR over 3.2% Ru/Al₂O₃ catalyst. Jakobsen et al., [38] reported an activation energy of 107.9 kJ/mol for MSR over 1%Ru/ZrO₂ catalyst, while Soria et al. [40] calculated an activation energy of 140 kJ/mol for MSR on a 4 wt% Ru/SiO₂ catalyst. In the present work, the calculated adsorption enthalpy of CO was found to be 83.6 kJ/mol, closely matching the value of 87 kJ/mol reported for Ru/ZrO₂ [38], and falls within the range of 50–115 kJ/mol as reported in the literature [73–76]. The relatively lower CO adsorption enthalpy in this study could be attributed to the higher surface coverage resulting from higher methane conversion in the integral reactor. This observation suggests the presence of a nonuniform catalyst surface and/or lateral interactions among the adsorbed species [77]. When measuring and evaluating the adsorption parameters from experimental data, it is crucial to ensure thermodynamic consistency, and the parameters must satisfy several thermodynamic criteria [78]: 1. Adsorption is indeed an exothermic process, and the negative enthalpy changes of ∆ H CO 0 = − 88.4 < 0 kJ / mol satisfies this rule. 2. The entropy should decrease after adsorption and the relevant criterion is ∆ S CO 0 < 0 or 0 < K CO , 0 = exp ∆ S CO 0 R < 1 . The pre-exponential term in the adsorption constant, K CO , 0 = 9.59 e − 7 , is less than 1, satisfying this criterion for CO. 3. The third rule states that ln K CO , 0 ≤ ( 12.2 − 0.0014 ∆ H CO ) / R ) , and the estimated value of − 13.857 ≤ 27.08 satisfies this rule. 4. The absolute value of entropy changes ∆ S j 0 should be larger than 42 J / ( mol K ) . The value of ∆ S CO 0 = − ln A CO . R = 115.2 J / ( mol . K ) satisfies this rule. 3.8 Comparison of ruthenium supported catalysts There have been few kinetic investigations of methane reforming reactions using ruthenium based catalysts, including Ru/Al₂O₃ [16], RuZrO₂ [38], Ru/La₂O₃ [53], Ru/SiO₂ [40], and Ru/(Al₂O₃-MnO₂) [37]. However, these studies were conducted under different operating condition, making direct comparison of their performances challenging. To quantitatively assess the relative catalytic activity of different catalysts, turnover frequency (TOF) is an important metric. TOF measures the number of molecules reacting on a single active site per unit time and provides a convenient way to compare catalysts that have been synthesised and tested under different conditions. TOF s − 1 = r f * MW Ru D * x Ru where, r f is the forward reaction rate calculated from the kinetic models, MW Ru is the molecular weight of ruthenium, D is the dispersion of Ru catalyst, x Ru is the weight fraction of Ru on the support. The forward reaction rates of the catalysts were calculated from the kinetic models under the operating conditions of S / C of 3.0, H₂/CH₄ of 1.0, 140 kPa, He/CH₄ ratio of 0.1, and temperature of 500 °C. The gas mixture composition was calculated for a methane conversion of 10%, assuming the water gas shift reaction to be at equilibrium. The turnover frequencies of the catalysts are depicted in Fig. 12. Based on the turnover frequencies, it can be observed that the catalytic activity of Ru/La-Al₂O₃ is the highest among the other reported Ru-based catalysts in the literature. This difference in activity could be attributed to variations in catalyst synthesis methods and different reaction mechanisms, particularly the shift of majority of steam dissociation from Ru active sites to lanthanum cations in the higher surface area alumina support. 4 Conclusion This study investigated the intrinsic kinetic of low-temperature methane steam reforming over Ru/La-Al₂O3 catalyst. The experiments were conducted at temperature ranging from 475 to 550 °C and a pressure of 140 kPa. Preliminary tests demonstrated stable catalytic activity, and the kinetic experiments were carried out in integral mode, with no mass and heat transport limitations. The steam reforming reaction was found to be first order with respect to methane and exhibited a partial positive order for steam. No competition was observed between methane and steam for the active sites. Notably, the inhibitory effect of CO was stronger than that of H₂, while the reaction showed zero order dependence on CO₂. A reaction mechanism was proposed to elucidate methane steam reforming, involving the dissociative-adsorption of methane on the metal catalyst and steam on the support. The formation of CO was assumed to take place at the metal-support interface, with carbon on Ru and OH on the support playing crucial roles. To describe the kinetics, a kinetic model was developed using Langmuir-Hinshelwood-Hougen-Watson (LHHW) approach. Methane dissociative adsorption was identified as the rate controlling step, with CO partly covering the active sites. The developed model exhibited statistical significance, thermodynamically consistency, and the best fit to the experimental data. The activity of the Ru/La-Al₂O3 catalyst was quantified in terms of TOF and compared with other Ru-based catalysts reported in the literature, and it was found to be the most active catalyst. coredata.dc:description: This study focuses on investigating the intrinsic kinetics of methane steam reforming over a lanthanum promoted Ru/La-Al₂O₃ catalyst at low temperatures ranging from 475 to 550 °C and 140 kPa. To facilitate the research, high-throughput experimentation was employed using 16 integral fixed bed reactors. The steam reforming reaction was influenced by co-reactants and products. In this work, we proposed a reaction mechanism and developed a kinetic model to understand the underlying process. The findings indicate that methane dissociative adsorption is the rate-determining step, and CO is identified as the most abundant surface intermediate. The developed kinetic model not only provides the best fit to the experimental data but also statistically significant and thermodynamically consistent.
coredata.dc:title: Intrinsic kinetics of low temperature methane steam reforming on Ru/La-Al₂O₃ catalyst
